Higgins|Robert Higgins]] | leader_since2 = 1971 | party2 = New Brunswick Liberal Association | leaders_seat2 = [[Saint John Park]] | last_election2 = 26 | seats2 = 25 | seat_change2 = -1 | popular_vote2 = | percentage2 = 47.52% | swing2 = -1.08 | map_image = NB1974.gif | map_size = 250px | map_caption = Map of New Brunswick's ridings coloured in based on the winning parties | title = Premier | before_election = [[Richard Hatfield]] | before_party = Progressive Conservative Party of New Brunswick | after_election = [[Richard Hatfield]] | after_party = Progressive Conservative Party of New Brunswick }} The '''28th New Brunswick general election''' was held on November 18, 1974, to elect 58 members to the [[48th New Brunswick Legislative Assembly]], the governing house of the [[Provinces and territories of Canada|province]] of [[New Brunswick]], [[Canada]]. It saw [[Richard Hatfield]]'s [[Progressive Conservative Party of New Brunswick]] win its second [[majority government]] with a gain of one seat despite losing the [[popular vote]] to [[Robert J. Higgins|Robert Higgins']] [[New Brunswick Liberal Party]]. It was the second election in a row in which the Conservatives received a majority in the parlieament despite receiving fewer votes than the Liberals. Despite the Hatfield government's involvement in the failed [[Bricklin SV-1]] automobile plant, and a series of kickback schemes, there were few surprises during the campaign. Hatfield had made inroads in the [[Acadian]] community since the [[New Brunswick general election, 1970|1970 election]], winning three [[francophone]] seats in [[by-election]]s. The Acadian support proved key during Hatfield's entire term as premier.
